§s 1-101State action
(a)In general.The Maryland Building Performance Standards are adopted and, from time to time, amended by the Maryland Department of Labor under State Public Safety Article, Title 12, Subtitle 5.
(b)Contents.As amended effective May 29, 2023, these Standards consist of:
(1)the International Building Code (2021 Edition), with certain State modifications {COMAR 09.12.51.04A and B};
(2)the International Residential Code for One- and Two-Family Dwellings (2021 Edition), with certain State modifications {COMAR 09.12.51.04A and C}; and
(3)the International Energy Conservation Code (2021 Edition), with certain State modifications {COMAR 09.12.51.04A and D}.

section.heading: City adoption
section.text: The Maryland Building Performance Standards are adopted as part of the Building, Fire, and Related Codes of Baltimore City, subject to the following modifications:

para.text: in the International Building Code (2021 Edition):
incorporate the State modifications indicated in the appropriate chapter, section, or other provision of Part II below; and
add the Baltimore City modifications indicated in the appropriate chapter, section, or other provision of Part II below;
in the International Residential Code for One- and Two-Family Dwellings (2021 Edition):
incorporate the State modifications indicated in the appropriate chapter, section, or other provision of Part X below; and
add the Baltimore City modifications indicated in the appropriate chapter, section, or other provision of Part X below; and
in the International Energy Conservation Code (2021 Edition):
incorporate the State modifications indicated in the appropriate chapter, section, or other provision of Parts IX-A and XI-B below; and
add the Baltimore City modifications indicated in the appropriate chapter, section, or other provision of Parts IX-A and XI-B below.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The International Building Code (2021 Edition) is adopted as part of the Building, Fire, and Related Codes of Baltimore City, subject to the additions, deletions, amendments, and other modifications contained in this Part II.

para.heading: Codification.
para.text: Unless otherwise specified, chapter and section numbers in this Part II refer to the chapter and section numbers of the International Building Code.

para.heading: Title.
para.text: The regulations contained in this Code constitute and are known as the "Baltimore City Building Code". The Baltimore City Building Code, together with the standards and codes listed in § 101.4 {"Referenced codes"} of this Chapter, as supplemented, amended, or otherwise modified by these provisions, collectively constitute and are known as the "Building, Fire, and Related Codes of Baltimore City".

para.heading: References to "this Code".
para.text: Throughout this Part II, all references to "this Code" refer to the Building, Fire, and Related Codes of Baltimore City.

para.heading: Scope.
para.text: Exception 1: {Per MBPS Modification} Detached 1- and 2-family dwellings and multiple single-family dwellings (townhouses) not more than 3 stories above grade plane in height with a separate means of egress and their accessory structures must comply with the International Residential Code.

Exception 2: {Per MBPS Modification} Existing buildings undergoing repair, alterations, or additions, and change of occupancy must comply with the Maryland Building Rehabilitation Code, set forth in COMAR 09.12.58. {Note: The Maryland Building Rehabilitation Code comprises the 2021 International Existing Building Code, with State modifications.}
Exception 3: {Per MBPS Modification} Maintenance of residential structures and premises must comply with the Minimum Livability Code, as set forth in COMAR 09.12.54.

para.heading: Appendices.
para.text: The appendices to the International Building Code apply as follows:

para.heading: Appendices adopted.
para.text: The following appendices are adopted, with or without local modifications, as part of this Code:
Appendix C: "Group U – Agricultural Buildings".
Appendix D: "Downtown Fire District".
Appendix F: "Rodent Proofing".
Appendix H: "Signs".
Appendix I: "Patio Covers".
Appendix J: "Grading".

para.heading: Appendices not adopted.
para.text: The following appendices are not adopted as part of this Code:
Appendix A: "Employee Qualifications".
Appendix B: "Board of Appeals".
Appendix E: "Supplementary Accessibility Requirements".
Appendix G: "Flood Resistant Construction".
Appendix K: "Administrative Provisions".
Appendix L: "Earthquake Recording Instrumentation".
Appendix M: "Tsunami-Generated Flood Hazard".
Appendix N. "Replicable Buildings"

para.heading: Referenced codes.
para.text: The standards and codes listed in this § 101.4, as modified by these provisions and as referred to elsewhere in this Code, are part of the requirements of this Code to the extent prescribed by the reference.

para.heading: Electrical.
para.text: The National Electrical Code (2020 Edition), as modified in Part III of this Code, applies to the installation of electrical systems, including their alteration, repair, replacement, equipment, appliances, fixtures, fittings, and appurtenances.

para.heading: Gas.
para.text: The International Fuel Gas Code (2021 Edition), as modified in Part IV of this Code, applies to the installation of gas piping from the point of delivery, to gas appliances, and to related accessories as covered in this Code. These requirements apply to gas piping systems extending from the point of delivery to the inlet connections of appliances and the installation and operation of residential and commercial gas appliances, and related accessories.

para.heading: Mechanical.
para.text: The International Mechanical Code (2021 Edition), as modified in Part V of this Code, applies to the installation, alterations, repairs, and replacement of mechanical systems, including equipment, appliances, fixtures, fittings, and appurtenances, including ventilating, heating, cooling, air-conditioning and refrigeration systems, incinerators, and other energy-related systems.

para.heading: Plumbing.
para.text: The International Plumbing Code (2021 Edition), as modified in Part VI of this Code, applies to the installation, alteration, repair, and replacement, use, or maintenance of or addition to plumbing systems, including equipment, appliances, fixtures, fittings, and appurtenances.

para.heading: Property maintenance.
para.text: The International Property Maintenance Code (2021 Edition), as modified in Part VII of this Code, applies to existing structures and premises; equipment and facilities; light, ventilation, space heating, sanitation, life, and fire safety hazards; responsibilities of owners, operators, and occupants; and occupancy of existing premises and structures.

para.heading: Fire prevention.
para.text: The International Fire Code (2021 Edition), as modified in Part VIII of this Code, applies to matters affecting or relating to prevention of structures, processes, and premises from the hazard of fire and explosion arising from the storage, handling or use of structures, materials, or devices; from conditions hazardous to life, property, or public welfare in the occupancy of structures or premises; and from the construction, extension, repair, alteration or removal of fire suppression, automatic sprinkler systems and alarm systems or fire hazards in the structure or on the premises from occupancy or operation.

para.heading: Energy.
para.text: The International Energy Conservation Code (2021 Edition), as modified in Parts IX-A and IX-B of this Code, applies to all matters governing the design and construction of buildings for energy efficiency.

para.heading: Residential.
para.text: The International Residential Code for One- and Two-Family Dwellings (2021 Edition), as modified in Part X of this Code, applies to detached 1- and 2-family dwellings and multiple single-family dwellings (townhouses), not more than 3 stories above grade plane in height, and their accessory structures.

para.heading: Green Construction.
para.text: The International Green Construction Code Construction (2021 Edition), as modified in Part XI of this Code, applies to construction requirements intended to reduce the negative impacts and increase the positive impacts of the built environment on the natural environment and building occupants.

para.heading: Swimming Pool and Spa.
para.text: The International Swimming Pool and Spa Code (2021 Edition), as modified in Part XII of this Code, applies to the construction, alteration, movement, renovation, replacement, repair and maintenance of aquatic recreation facilities, pools and spas.

para.heading: References to former Codes.
para.text: All references in a violation, condemnation, or other notice, in a citation, or in the Baltimore City Code to any former version of the Building Code or to any provision of that Code are considered to refer to the comparable or otherwise applicable provisions of this Code.

para.heading: Enforcement agency.
para.text: This Code is administered and enforced by the Baltimore City Department of Housing and Community Development and its Commissioner. Accordingly, in this Code:
"Department of Building Safety" or "Department" means the Baltimore City Department of Housing and Community Development, and
"Building Official", means the Commissioner of Housing and Community Development or an authorized representative of the Commissioner.

para.heading: Employee restrictions.
para.text: An officer or employee of the Department may not:

engage in or directly or indirectly be connected with the furnishing of labor, materials, or appliances or the preparation of plans or specifications for the construction, alteration, addition, repair, rehabilitation, demolition, moving, or maintenance of a structure, unless the officer or employee is the owner of the structure, or
engage in any work that conflicts with his or her official duties or with the interests of the Department.

para.heading: Service of notice – Unoccupied property.
para.text: If the structure or premises is unoccupied, the notice must be mailed or delivered to the last-known address of the owner, agent, or other person in apparent control.

para.heading: Required.
para.text: A permit issued by the Building Official is required before any person may do any of the following work:
construct, alter, add to, repair, rehabilitate, demolish, or move any structure,
change the use of any structure or land,
install or alter any equipment subject to this Code,
move a lot line that affects any structure,
perform any grading or excavating,
undertake, cause, or allow any addition, alteration or other action described in either of the following provisions of City Code Article 6 {"Historical and Architectural Preservation"}:
§ 8-2(a) {"Building permit required: Exterior structures"}, describing actions for or with respect to any structure:
within an Historical and Architectural Preservation District,
on the Landmark List: Exteriors, or
on the potential-Landmark List: Exteriors, or
§ 8-2(b) {"Building permit required: Public interiors"}, describing actions for or with respect to any structure:
on the Landmark List: Public Interiors, or
on the potential-Landmark List: Public Interiors, or
on transfer of ownership or operation of property, continue any of the following uses:
banquet hall (as defined in Baltimore City Zoning Code § 1-303(c) {"Banquet hall."}),
body art establishment (as defined in Baltimore City Zoning Code § 1-303(j) {"Body art establishment."}),
carry-out food shop (as defined in Baltimore City Zoning Code § 1-303(t) {"Carry-out food shop."}),
congregate living facilities (as defined in § 202.1 of the Baltimore City Building Code),
day-care center: adult or child (as defined in Baltimore City Zoning Code §§ 1-304(z) and 1-305(a) {"Day-care center: Child," and "Day-care center: Adult"}),
drive-through facility (as defined in Baltimore City Zoning Code § 1-305(h) {"Drive-through facility."}),
entertainment: indoor or live (as defined in Baltimore City Zoning Code §§ 1-306(b) and 1-306(c) {"Entertainment: Indoor." and "Entertainment: Live"}),
fuel station (as defined in Baltimore City Zoning Code § 1-306(t) {"Fuel station."}),
health-care clinic (as defined in Baltimore City Zoning Code § 1-307(f) {"Health-care clinic."}),
lodge or social club (as defined in Baltimore City Zoning Code § 1-308(q) {"Lodge or social club."}),
lounge (as defined in Baltimore City Zoning Code § 1-309(h-1) {"Lounge."}),
pawn shop (as defined in Baltimore City Zoning Code § 1-311(l) {"Pawn shop."}),
personal services establishment (as defined in Baltimore City Zoning Code § 1-311(o) {"Personal services establishment."}),
residential care facility (as defined in Baltimore City Zoning Code § 1-312(p) {"Residential care facility"}),
restaurant (as defined in Baltimore City Zoning Code § 1-312(s) {"Restaurant."}),
retail: big box establishment,
retail goods establishment – with or without alcoholic beverage sales (as defined in Baltimore City Zoning Code § 1-312(u) {"Retail goods establishment."}),
rooming house (as defined in Baltimore City Zoning Code § 1-313(b) {"Rooming house."}),
supportive housing facility (as defined in § 202.2.56 of this Code), or
tavern (as defined in Baltimore City Zoning Code § 1-314(a) {"Tavern."}).

para.heading: By whom application to be made.
para.text: Except as otherwise specified in Chapter 27 {"Electrical"}, Chapter 28 {"Mechanical Systems"}, and Chapter 29 {"Plumbing Systems"}, the application for a permit must be made as follows:
for a demolition or moving permit, by the owner of the property to be demolished or moved,
for a permit to remove formstone, paint, or other material from exterior surfaces, by the licensed contractor employed to do the proposed work,
for a permit to do work involving underpinning or a retaining foundation wall, by the licensed contractor employed to do the proposed work, and
for all other permits, by:
the owner or lessee of the structure,
the agent of the owner or lessee, or
the licensed engineer or architect employed in connection with the proposed work.

para.heading: Work done without permit.
para.text: A person who does any work without a permit, or outside or beyond the scope of a permit, or in a manner inconsistent with plans or drawings approved as part of a permit application, or after a permit is revoked for any reason, must obtain a permit for that work, even if already completed, and pay the appropriate permit fee and penalty surcharge.

para.heading: Special professional services.
para.text: In addition to and without limiting any other requirements of or authority granted by this Code, the Building Official may require, as a term or condition of a permit, that a registered design professional or other licensed specialist or expert perform specific work or sign and seal specific plans, computations, specifications, or statements.

para.heading: Application for permit.
para.text: To obtain a permit, the applicant must first file an application on the form provided by the Building Official for that purpose. The application must:
identify and describe the work to be covered under the permit,
describe the land on which the proposed work is to be done by legal description, street address, or similar description that will readily identify and definitely locate the proposed building or work,
indicate the use and occupancy for which the proposed work is intended,
specify the gross floor area, as defined in Baltimore City Zoning Code § 1-306(j) {"Floor Area: Gross (GFA)"}, involved in the proposed work,
specify the number of dwelling units, if any, involved in the proposed work,
be accompanied by the construction documents and other information required by § 107 {"Construction Documents"} of this Code, and

if the property is located within an Historical and Architectural Preservation District or included on the City's Landmark List or Potential-Landmark List, be forwarded to the Commission for Historical and Architectural Preservation, for review and action under City Code Article 6 {"Historical and Architectural Preservation"}, Subtitle 8 {"Alterations, etc., to or Affecting Properties"},
state the valuation of the proposed work,
if the proposed work will replace any existing structure, be accompanied by photographs that depict the existing conditions and existing structures on the site,
include a detailed disposal plan on the form provided by the Building Official for that purpose, if:
the proposed work includes interior or exterior demolition, and
the Building Official requires the applicant to provide a detailed disposal plan,
identify the parties by providing:
the full names, phone numbers, addresses, and (if available) email addresses of the owner, lessee, and applicant,
the full name, phone number, address, and (if available) email address of a person who can be contacted at all times in case of an emergency, and

if the owner, lessee, or applicant is a corporation, partnership, limited liability company, or other entity, full names, phone numbers, addresses, and (if available) email addresses of its officers, partners, or members, as the case may be,
provide any other data and information that the Building Official requires,
be signed by the applicant, or the applicant's authorized agent,
if signed by an agent, be accompanied by:
proof of agency, and
proof of the agent's identity, by copy or presentation of a valid Maryland driver's license or other Maryland identification, and
if the application is for a permit for public assemblies – annual or a permit for public assemblies – short term, as described in section 109.6.5 of this Code, the application shall be:
filed at least 45 days before the event date, and
signed by the applicant or the applicant’s agent.

para.heading: General.
para.text: The Building Official must examine all applications for permits within a reasonable time after filing. If the application or the proposed work does not conform to the requirements of this Code or any other applicable law, the Building Official must reject the application in writing, stating the reasons for the rejection. If the Building Official is satisfied that the application and the proposed work conform to the requirements of this Code and all other applicable laws, the Building Official must issue the permit as soon as practicable.

para.heading: Referral to assess need for traffic mitigation.
para.text: Within 15 business days of receiving a completed application, the Building Official must refer the application and all accompanying documents to the Director of Transportation, for review and action under Chapter 38 {"Traffic Impact and Mitigation"} of this Code, if:
traffic mitigation requirements for the proposed work have not already been complied with in accordance with this Code or the Baltimore City Zoning Code; and
the proposed work:
is in a Traffic-Mitigation Zone designated under Chapter 38 {"Traffic Impact and Mitigation"} of this Code and involves 10 or more dwelling units,
involves 15,000 sq. ft. or more of gross floor area (as defined in Baltimore City Zoning Code § 1-306(j)), or
involves 50 or more dwelling units.

para.heading: Bond for exterior removal of formstone, paint, etc.
para.text: An application for a permit to remove formstone, paint, or other material from exterior surfaces must be accompanied by evidence satisfactory to the Building Official that the applicant has obtained a bond to cover the City's expense in the event of a spill or failure to properly dispose of hazardous waste. The bond must be in an amount of at least $10,000.

para.heading: Expiration; extension; reinstatement for final inspection.
para.text: Unless an extension is granted, every permit expires and becomes invalid on the expiration date specified on the permit or, if earlier, as provided in this § 105.5.

para.heading: Expiration – General.
para.text: Except as specified in § 105.5.2, a permit expires if:
the work authorized by the permit is not begun on the site within 180 days after the permit is issued, or
the work authorized by the permit is abandoned or suspended on the site for 180 days or more.

para.heading: Expiration – Condemnation, demolition.
para.text: A permit issued to comply with a condemnation notice served under § 123 {"Notices"} of this Code or to comply with a demolition order issued under § 116 {"Unsafe Structures"} of this Code expires if:
the work authorized by the permit is not begun on the site within 30 days after the permit is issued, or
the work authorized by the permit is not completed within 90 days after the permit is issued.

para.heading: Extensions – General.
para.text: On a timely written application and for justifiable cause demonstrated, the Building Official may grant 1 or more extensions. Except as specified in § 105.5.5:
the application for an extension must be made within 90 days after the permit expires, and
each extension is limited to a period of not more than 180 days, unless otherwise authorized by the Building Official.

para.heading: Extensions – Condemnation, demolition.
para.text: For a permit issued to comply with a condemnation notice or a demolition order:
the application for an extension must be made within 90 days after the date that the permit expired and
each extension must be limited to a period of not more than 90 days.

para.heading: Reinstatement for final inspection.
para.text: An expired permit may be reinstated by the Building Official for a final inspection if:
the application for reinstatement is made within 3 years of the permit's expiration;
all rough-in inspections were completed and approved by the Building Official; and
all of the work is complete.

para.heading: Single reinstatement allowed.
para.text: An expired permit may be reinstated by the Building Official for a final inspection only once.

para.heading: Compliance with violation notice or order.
para.text: The expiration date of a permit does not in any way extend the time required to comply with a violation notice or order.

para.heading: General.
para.text: Exception 2: Construction documents may be submitted electronically through the City's permit system if the submission complies with the guidelines established in the Permit Applicant User Guide.

para.heading: Site plan.
para.text: The construction documents submitted with the application for permit must be accompanied by a site plan.

para.heading: General requirements.
para.text: The site plan must:
show to scale the size and location of new construction and existing structures on the site, distances from lot lines, the established street grades, and the proposed finished grades,
show, as applicable, Regulated Flood Hazard Areas, Floodways, and flood-protection elevations,
be drawn in accordance with an accurate boundary line survey, and
comport with all other requirements of this section.

para.heading: Demolition.
para.text: In the case of demolition, the site plan must show construction to be demolished and the location and size of existing structures and construction that are to remain on the site.

para.heading: Specifications, photographs, additional information.
para.text: The site plan must:
be drawn in accordance with the specifications required by rules or regulations adopted by the Building Official in consultation with the Director ofTransportation, and
contain any additional information required by those rules or regulations.

para.heading: Exterior balconies and elevated walking surfaces.
Waiver or modification.
para.text: The Building Official may waive or modify the requirement for a site plan if the application is for alteration or repair or if otherwise warranted.

para.heading: Permit extensions.
para.text: For a permit extension issued under this Code, the charge is as follows:
If the application for extension is made within 90 days after the permit expires, the fee for the extension is $25.

If the application for extension is made between 31-90 days after the permit expires, the fee for the extension is 50% of the original permit fee. Alternatively, the applicant may apply for a new permit for the work remaining to be completed, with the fee for that permit to be based on the scope of that remaining work.

para.heading: Uncollected payments.
para.text: The charge for each unsuccessful attempt to collect a payment is $50.

para.heading: Installing on-premises advertising signs.
para.text: For erecting, placing, hanging, or reconstructing any consolidated area of signage, as described in Baltimore City Zoning Code Title 17, Subtitle 3 {"Sign Dimension and Quantity Measurement Methodology"}, the fee is $1 a square foot, with a minimum of $13 for each consolidated area of signage.

The rates in items j and k are based on the gross square feet area of the sign face or faces. No fee is charged for signs less than 100 square feet (9.29 sq. m.) and used exclusively for advertising the sale or lease of the property on which they are posted.
For repairing, painting, and rehanging any sign in the same place, the fee is $25 for each sign.

para.heading: Lowest floor elevation.
para.text: In a flood hazard area, on placement of the lowest floor and before undertaking any further vertical construction, the elevation certificate required by the Floodplain Management Code must be submitted to the Building Official.

para.heading: Final inspection.
para.text: The final inspection must be made after all work required by the building permit is completed.

para.heading: Flood hazard documentation.
para.text: For structures in a flood hazard area, documentation of the elevation of the lowest floor, as required by the Floodplain Management Code, must be submitted to the Building Official before the final inspection.

para.heading: Enforcement generally.
para.text: If a violation is not discontinued or abated within 14 days of the issuance of a violation notice, or if the violation notice or order is not complied with within 14 days of the issuance of a violation notice, the Building Official may institute or cause to be instituted any appropriate legal proceedings. Provided however, for an emergent issue, as determined by the Building Official, the 14 day period to abate or comply with the notice or order may be waived by the Building Official and the Building Official may institute or cause to be instituted any appropriate legal proceedings.

para.heading: Types of proceedings.
para.text: Enforcement proceedings may include:
injunctive or other equity proceedings, including:
an action initiated by a code-enforcement-injunction citation under City Code Article 19, § 71-3 {"Code enforcement injunction"}, or
an action for appointment of a receiver under § 121 {"Vacant Building Receiver"} of this Code,
criminal prosecution, including a prosecution initiated by a prepayable criminal citation under City Code Article 19, § 71-2 {"Prepayable criminal citations"}, and
administrative proceedings, including one initiated by an environmental citation under City Code Article 1, § 40-14 {"Violations to which subtitle applies"}.

para.heading: Remedies not exclusive.
para.text: In pursuing a violation, the Building Official may use any 1 or more available remedies or enforcement actions. The initiation of any 1 remedy or enforcement action does not preclude pursuing any other remedy or enforcement action authorized by law. Neither damages, irreparable injury, nor the lack of an adequate remedy at law is a prerequisite to enforcement in equity.

para.heading: When prior notice not required.
para.text: A violation notice or order is not a prerequisite to enforcement action in the following situations:
when seeking a temporary restraining order or injunction in an emergency,
when seeking equitable relief for a pattern or practice of noncompliance,
for work being done without a permit or in violation of a stop-work order,
for a violation that remains unabated after a prior prosecution for that violation,

for a prepayable criminal citation that is issued under City Code Article 19, Subtitle 71 {"Special Enforcement Officers"} and for which prior notice is waived under Article 19, § 71-2 {"Prepayable criminal citations"},
for an environmental citation that is issued under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 40 {"Environmental Control Board"},
for occupying or causing to be occupied a building that is subject to a violation notice issued under § 116 {"Unsafe Structures"} or § 120 {"Condemnation Proceedings"}, and
in any other case specifically authorized by this Code.

para.heading: Violation a misdemeanor.
para.text: A person is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, subject to the penalties specified in this § 114.4, if the person:
violates a provision of this Code,
fails to comply with any requirement of this Code or of a {rule,} regulation, order, decision, permit, or notice issued under this Code, or

constructs, alters, adds to, repairs, rehabilitates, demolishes, moves, locates, uses, occupies, or maintains any structure, premises, land, or equipment in violation of an approved plan or directive of the Building Official or of a permit or certificate issued under this Code.

para.heading: Notice required.
para.text: Except as otherwise specifically authorized by law, criminal proceedings may not be initiated unless the Building Official issues a notice of violation and allows a period within which to abate the violation.

para.heading: Each day a separate offense.
para.text: If a violation is not discontinued, abated, or complied with within 14 days from the issuance of a violation notice, each day thereafter that a violation continues is a separate offense. Proof that a violation exists on any date after issuance of a violation notice is prima facie evidence that the violation has continued unabated throughout the intervening period.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: The penalty for each offense is a fine of not more than $500.

para.heading: Issuance.
para.text: The stop-work order must be in writing and state the reason for the order. It must be posted on the property. On posting, the cited work must immediately cease. Written notice of the stop-work order must be sent by first class and certified mail to the owner of the property involved.

para.heading: Removal, etc., of posted notice.
para.text: Until the Building Official so authorizes, no person may remove, deface, damage, or change any notice, poster, or sign placed under this section on any land, structure, or other object.

para.heading: Vacant structures.
para.text: Every vacant structure, as defined in this § 116.4, is declared to be a fire hazard and a nuisance per se, and must be safeguarded and otherwise maintained as required in this § 116.4.

para.heading: General.
para.text: In this § 116.4, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Vacant structure.
para.text: "Vacant structure" means a structure or distinguishable part of a structure that is:
unoccupied, and
either:
unsafe or unfit for human habitation or other authorized use, or
a nuisance property.

para.heading: Nuisance property.
para.text: "Nuisance property" means:

an unoccupied structure for which 2 or more final, non-appealable Building Code, Fire Code, or Property Maintenance Code violations remained unabated for 10 days or more beyond the date by which the violation notice, citation, or order required the violation to be corrected; or

the exterior premises of an unoccupied structure for which, at any time within the preceding 12 months, on 6 or more separate occasions, final, no-longer appealable violation notices, citations, or orders were served to correct violations of Property Maintenance Code, § 305 {"Exterior Sanitary Maintenance – General"} or § 306 {"Exterior Sanitary Maintenance – Trash, Garbage, and Debris"}.

para.heading: Registration authorized.
para.text: A holder of an interest in a structure by way of a mortgage or deed of trust may register that interest in the Housing Commissioner's Registry of Non-Owner-Occupied Dwellings, Rooming Houses, and Vacant Structures (City Code Article 13, Subtitle 4).

para.heading: Notice required to registrants.
para.text: Before declaring an unoccupied structure to be a nuisance property, the Building Official must send a notice, by first-class mail or email, to any interest holder that is registered for that structure under City Code Article 13, Subtitle 4 {"Registration of Non-Owner-Occupied Dwellings, Rooming Houses, and Vacant Structures"}.

para.heading: Tenor of notice.
para.text: The notice shall provide the interest holder with the opportunity to avoid a declaration of public nuisance if, within 30 days of the mailing, the interest holder:
abates all outstanding violations; and
submits a reasonable plan to the Building Commissioner for regular maintenance of the property.

para.heading: Official's corrective actions do not constitute abatement.
para.text: Actions taken by the Building Official to clean, secure, or repair a property do not preclude the Building Official's determination that the property is a nuisance property.

para.heading: Determination of vacancy, noncompliance.
para.text: A determination of vacancy and a determination of noncompliance with a notice or order issued under this section may be based on observation that a structure:
contains, at any level, any open window or door, any opening caused by damage or decay, or any other opening that is unprotected from intruders,
has boarded windows or doors, or
lacks intact doors, windows, window sashes, walls, or roof surfaces to protect against the elements.

para.heading: Required safeguarding.
para.text: Every vacant structure must be cleaned, closed, and safeguarded as follows:
Before the structure is closed and secured, all litter, trash, and other debris must be removed from the premises.

All windows, doors, and other openings must be closed, securely locked, and, if readily accessible, boarded up with substantial material, including masonry, approved by the Building Official. The Building Official may require windows facing streets to be boarded with lexan, vinyl, or similar material, protected by security grills, or both.
As long as the structure remains unrehabilitated:
it must be kept boarded,
the premises must be conspicuously posted against trespass, and
the premises must be kept free of occupants, litter, trash, debris, high grass, and weeds at all times, and
the structure's roof and flashing must be sound, right, and without defects that admit rain.
Boarding, posting, and cleaning, however, do not relieve the owner of responsibility to demolish or to repair and maintain the property in conformity with this Code.
The Building Official may post a sign to inform the public that the structure is a vacant structure and to provide additional information about the structure's status.
The structure may not be reoccupied until the Building Official has issued an occupancy permit.

para.heading: Emergency condition.
para.text: A vacant structure that is not kept boarded and free from accumulations of debris and high vegetation or that, in the opinion of the Building Official, is so dangerously unsound or so deteriorated that rehabilitation is not feasible, constitutes an emergency condition that imminently threatens the public health and safety and requires immediate resolution.

para.heading: Rodenticide procedure.
para.text: See § 3318 of this Code.

para.heading: Notice to Public Works.
para.text: Whenever the Building Official determines a structure to be vacant, the Building Official must promptly notify the Director of Public Works of that determination. On receipt of the notice, the Director of Public Works must proceed to cut off water service, as provided in City Code Article 24, § 2-3 {"Cut-off for arrearage"}.

para.heading: Contents – Condemnation notices.
para.text: Except as specified in § 123.3.1, every condemnation notice must set forth:
the location of the condemned structure or equipment,
the reason the structure or equipment is condemned,
a reference to applicable provisions of this Code,
a warning against entering or using the condemned structure or equipment,
the right of the person to whom the notice is directed to request a hearing within 21 days of the date on which the notice was served, and
unless to be contained in a follow-up or subsequent notice:
a statement of the requirements that must be complied with to rectify the unsafe condition,
the time within which the unsafe condition must be rectified, and
the Building Official's authority under § 123.8 {"Failure to comply with notice or citation"} to take action at the owner's expense.

para.heading: Follow-up notices.
para.text: A follow-up or other subsequent notice involving the same condemnation need not repeat the information contained in a prior notice as long as the subsequent notice identifies the prior notice.

para.heading: Violation notices.
para.text: Except as specified in § 123.4.1, every violation notice must set forth:
the location and character of the violation,
a reference to applicable provisions of this Code,
the right of the person to whom the notice is directed to request a hearing within 21 days of the date on which the notice was served, and
unless to be contained in a follow-up or subsequent notice:
a statement of the requirements that must be complied with to rectify the violation,
the time within which the violation must be rectified, and
the Building Official's authority under § 123.8 {"Failure to comply with notice or citation"} to take action at the owner's expense.

para.heading: Follow-up notices.
para.text: A follow-up or other subsequent notice involving the same violation need not repeat the information contained in a prior notice as long as the subsequent notice identifies the prior notice.

para.heading: General.
para.text: Except as provided in § 202.2 of this Code, terms that are used in this Code and defined in the International Building Code (2021 Edition) have the meanings given in the International Building Code (2021 Edition).

para.heading: Supplemental definitions.
para.text: Notwithstanding any different definition in the International Building Code, the following terms have the meanings given in this § 202.2.

para.heading: Accessory structure.
para.text: "Accessory structure" means a structure:
located on the same lot as the main structure, and
the use of which is incidental to that of the main structure.

para.heading: Agent.
para.text: "Agent" means, as the context indicates, any person who:
in any particular case involving any property:
is responsible for the management, maintenance, operation, rental, leasing, or sale of the property,
applies for or seeks a permit or certificate from a City authority on behalf of the owner of the property, or
in any way represents the owner of the property,
represents the Building Official, or
in general, represents another.

para.heading: Authorized use.
para.text: "Authorized use" means a use of land or structure approved in accordance with the Baltimore City Zoning Code.

para.heading: Base flood.
para.text: "Base flood" has the meaning stated in City Code Article 7 {"Natural Resources"}, § 1-2 {"Definitions – "Accessory structure" to "Floodplain District"}.

para.heading: Base-flood elevation.
para.text: "Base-flood elevation" has the meaning stated in City Code Article 7 {"Natural Resources"}, § 1-2 {"Definitions – "Accessory structure" to "Floodplain District"}.

para.heading: Blight.
para.text: "Blight" includes exterior surfaces defaced by carvings, markings, or graffiti.

para.heading: Building.
para.text: "Building" has the meaning stated in IBC § 202 and, unless the context indicates otherwise, includes premises and lands.

para.heading: Building Official.
para.text: "Building Official" has the meaning stated in § 103.1 {"Enforcement agency"}.

para.heading: Building permit.
para.text: "Building permit" means any permit issued under this Code.

para.heading: Certificate of occupancy.
para.text: "Certificate of occupancy" means an occupancy permit.

para.heading: Change in occupancy.
para.text: "Change in occupancy" means a change in the purpose or level of activity on land or within a structure.

para.heading: Change of use.
para.text: "Change of use" means change in occupancy.

para.heading: City.
para.text: "City" means the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore.

para.heading: Code.
para.text: "Code" means, unless otherwise specified, the Building, Fire, and Related Codes of Baltimore City, as further defined in § 101.1 {"Title"}.

para.heading: Cool Roof Rating Council.
para.text: "Cool Roof Rating Council" or "CRRC" means the Cool Roof Rating Council, Inc., an American National Standards Institute-Accredited Standards Developer Organization, that created, maintains, and updates the American National Standard: ANSI/CRRC S100 - "Standard Test Methods for Determining Radiative Properties of Materials".

para.heading: Demolition.
para.text: "Demolition":
means razing or demolition, and
includes removal of the debris resulting from any razing or demolition.

para.heading: Department.
para.text: "Department" means, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise, the Department of Building Safety, as further defined in § 103.1 {"Enforcement agency"}.

para.heading: Department of Building Safety.
para.text: "Department of Building Safety" has the meaning stated in § 103.1{"Enforcement agency"}.

para.heading: Design flood.
para.text: "Design flood" has the meaning stated in City Code Article 7 {"Natural Resources"}, § 1-2 {"Definitions – "Accessory structure" to "Floodplain District"}.

para.heading: Design-flood elevation.
para.text: "Design-flood elevation" has the meaning stated in City Code Article 7 {"Natural Resources"}, § 1-2 {"Definitions – "Accessory structure" to "Floodplain District"}.

para.heading: Dry floodproofing.
para.text: "Dry floodproofing" has the meaning stated in City Code Article 7 {"Natural Resources"}, § 1-2 {"Definitions – "Accessory structure" to "Floodplain District"}.

para.heading: Dwelling.
para.text: "Dwelling" includes, but is not limited to, any one or more of the following:

para.heading: Dormitory.
para.text: "Dormitory" means a space in a building that provides group sleeping accommodations in 1 room or in a series of closely associated rooms for persons not members of the same family group.

para.heading: Multiple-family dwelling.
para.text: "Multiple-family dwelling" means a building or part of a building that contains more than 2 dwelling units.

para.heading: 1-family dwelling; single-family dwelling unit.
para.text: "1-family dwelling" or "single-family dwelling unit" means a building that contains only 1 dwelling unit and is used only for that purpose.

para.heading: 2-family dwelling.
para.text: "2-family dwelling" means a building that contains 2 dwelling units and is used only for that purpose.

para.heading: Dwelling unit.
para.text: "Dwelling unit" means a single unit that provides or that is designed or intended to provide complete, independent living facilities for 1 or more persons, including permanent provisions for living, sleeping, eating, cooking, and sanitation.

para.heading: Existing structure (in Regulated Flood Hazard Areas).
para.text: "Existing structure" means any structure for which the building permit was issued before March 15, 1978, and the actual start of construction was within 180 days of the permit date, as defined in the Floodplain Management Code.

para.heading: "Actual start of construction".
para.text: For purposes of this definition, "actual start of construction" has the meaning stated in City Code Article 7 {"Natural Resources"}, § 1-2 {"Definitions – "Accessory structure" to "Floodplain District"}.

para.heading: Flood; Flooding.
para.text: "Flood" or "flooding" has the meaning stated in City Code Article 7 {"Natural Resources"}, § 1-2 {"Definitions – "Accessory structure" to "Floodplain District"}.

para.heading: Flood hazard area.
para.text: "Flood Hazard Area" means a Regulated Flood Hazard Area established under and regulated by the Floodplain Management Code.

para.heading: Flood Insurance Rate Map; FIRM.
para.text: "Flood Insurance Rate Map" or "FIRM" has the meaning stated in City Code Article 7 {"Natural Resources"}, § 1-2 {"Definitions – "Accessory structure" to "Floodplain District"}.

para.heading: Flood Insurance Study.
para.text: "Flood Insurance Study" has the meaning stated in City Code Article 7 {"Natural Resources"}, § 1-2 {"Definitions – "Accessory structure" to "Floodplain District"}.

para.heading: Floodplain Management Code.
para.text: "Floodplain Management Code" means the Baltimore City Floodplain Management Code, City Code Article 7 {"Natural Resources"}, Division I {"Floodplain Management"}.

para.heading: Floodway.
para.text: "Floodway" has the meaning stated in City Code Article 7 {"Natural Resources"}, § 1-3 {"Definitions – "Floodproofing" to "Wet floodproofing"}.

para.heading: Foster care facility.
para.text: "Foster care facility" means a facility that provides care to more than 8 children who are 2½ years of age or less.

para.heading: Historic structure.
para.text: "Historic structure" has the meaning stated in City Code Article 7 {"Natural Resources"}, § 1-3 {"Definitions – "Floodproofing" to "Wet floodproofing"}.

para.heading: Energy Conservation Code.
para.text: "Energy Conservation Code", "Baltimore City Energy Conservation Code", "International Energy Conservation Code", or "IECC" means the International Energy Conservation Code (2021 Edition), as supplemented, amended, or otherwise modified by Baltimore City.

para.heading: Fire Code.
para.text: "Fire Code", "Baltimore City Fire Code", "International Fire Code", or "IFC" means the International Fire Code (2021 Edition), as supplemented, amended, or otherwise modified by Baltimore City.

para.heading: Fuel Gas Code.
para.text: "Fuel Gas Code", "Baltimore City Fuel Gas Code", "International Fuel Gas Code", or "IFGC" means the International Fuel Gas Code (2021 Edition), as supplemented, amended, or otherwise modified by Baltimore City.

para.heading: Green Construction Code.
para.text: "Green Construction Code", "Baltimore City Green Construction Code", "International Green Construction Code", or "IgCC" means the International Green Construction Code (2021 Edition), as supplemented, amended, or otherwise modified by Baltimore City.

para.heading: Mechanical Code.
para.text: "Mechanical Code", "Baltimore City Mechanical Code", "International Mechanical Code", or "IMC" means the International Mechanical Code (2021 Edition), as supplemented, amended, or otherwise modified by Baltimore City.

para.heading: Plumbing Code.
para.text: "Plumbing Code", "Baltimore City Plumbing Code", "International Plumbing Code", or "IPC" means the International Plumbing Code (2021 Edition), as supplemented, amended, or otherwise modified by Baltimore City.

para.heading: Property Maintenance Code.
para.text: "Property Maintenance Code", "Baltimore City Property Maintenance Code", "International Property Maintenance Code",or "IPMC" means the International Property Maintenance Code (2021 Edition), as supplemented, amended, or otherwise modified by Baltimore City.

para.heading: Residential Code.
para.text: "Residential Code", "Baltimore City Residential Code", "International Residential Code", or "IRC" means the International Residential Code for One- and Two-Family Dwellings (2021 Edition), as supplemented, amended, or otherwise modified by Baltimore City.

para.heading: Swimming Pool and Spa Code.
para.text: "Swimming Pool and Spa Code", "Baltimore City Swimming Pool and Spa Code", "International Swimming Pool and Spa Code", or "ISPSC" means the International Swimming Pool and Spa Code (2021 Edition), as supplemented, amended, or otherwise modified by Baltimore City.

para.heading: Lowest floor.
para.text: "Lowest floor" has the meaning stated in City Code Article 7 {"Natural Resources"}, § 1-3 {"Definitions – "Floodproofing" to "Wet floodproofing"}.

para.heading: May not, etc.
para.text: "May not", "must not", and "no ... may" are each mandatory negative terms used to establish a prohibition.

para.heading: Mortgage.
para.text: "Mortgage" includes a deed of trust or other deed in the nature of a mortgage.

para.heading: Mortgagee.
para.text: "Mortgagee" includes a beneficiary under a deed of trust or other deed in the nature of a mortgage.

para.heading: Must/shall.
para.text: "Must" and "shall" are each mandatory terms used to express a requirement or to impose a duty.

para.heading: Electrical Code.
para.text: "Electrical Code", "Baltimore City Electrical Code", "National Electrical Code", or "NEC" means the National Electrical Code (2020 Edition), as supplemented, amended, or otherwise modified by Baltimore City.

para.heading: Occupancy.
para.text: "Occupancy" means:
the state of occupying or using any land or structure, or
the act of taking, holding possession of, or using any land or structure, or
the purpose for which any land or structure is used or occupied.

para.heading: Occupancy permit.
para.text: "Occupancy permit" means a permit that:
signifies compliance with this Code and related laws, and
indicates the Building Official's approval to occupy a structure for the authorized use.

para.heading: Occupant.
para.text: "Occupant" means any person who uses or who has the right of possession of all or any part of a structure or premises.

para.heading: Operator.
para.text: "Operator" means any person who has charge, care, or control of all or any part of a structure or premises.

para.heading: Person.
para.text: "Person":

means any individual, sole proprietorship, corporation, limited liability company, firm, partnership, association, organization, joint venture, or other entity or group acting as a unit, executor, administrator, trustee, receiver, guardian, or other representative appointed by law, and
whenever used in this Code with reference to liability or to the imposition of a penalty or fine, includes:
as to an unincorporated firm, partnership, association, organization, or joint venture, the partners or members of the firm, partnership, association, organization, or joint venture,
as to a corporation, the officers, trustees, agents, or members of the corporation who are responsible for the violation of any relevant code provision, and

in addition, the responsible officer, trustee, partner, or member designated on a registration statement filed under City Code Article 13, Subtitle 4 {"Registration of Non-Owner-Occupied Dwellings, etc."}.

para.heading: Premises.
para.text: "Premises" means a lot or group of lots, together with all or any part of any buildings or structures on the lot or group of lots, considered as a unit devoted to a particular use, including accessory structures and open spaces required or used in connection with that particular use.

para.heading: Rehabilitation.
para.text: "Rehabilitation" means all repairs and other work, of any kind, needed to make a dwelling or other structure fit to be occupied for its authorized use in conformity with all applicable standards and requirements of this Code.

para.heading: Related laws.
para.text: "Related laws" has the meaning stated in § 104.6.2 {"Authority to seek warrant"}.

para.heading: Structure.
para.text: "Structure" has the meaning stated in IBC § 202 and, unless the context indicates otherwise, includes premises and lands.

para.heading: Stabilization.
para.text: "Stabilization", with reference to a structure that has been declared unsafe or unfit for occupancy, means all work of any kind, not amounting to rehabilitation, that is needed, or that is performed or required by the Building Official, to make the structure safe and secure, to prevent its further deterioration, and to eliminate its blighting influence.

para.heading: Substantial damage.
para.text: "Substantial damage" has the meaning stated in City Code Article 7 {"Natural Resources"}, § 1-3 {"Definitions – "Floodproofing" to "Wet floodproofing"}.

para.heading: Substantial improvement.
para.text: "Substantial improvement" has the meaning stated in City Code Article 7 {"Natural Resources"}, § 1-3 {"Definitions – "Floodproofing" to "Wet floodproofing"}.

para.heading: Supportive housing facility.
para.text: "Supportive housing facility" means a non-institutional, shared living environment which integrates shelter, service, and support needs of socially isolated persons who are otherwise in good health, can maintain a semi-independent lifestyle, and do not require constant supervision or intensive health care as provided by an institution.

para.heading: Transfer.
para.text: "Transfer", when used with respect to property subject to this Code, has the meaning stated in § 114.23 {"Responsibility of transferee"}.

para.heading: Unsafe structure.
para.text: "Unsafe structure” means a structure:
that is unsafe, insanitary, or deficient because of inadequate means of egress facilities or inadequate light and ventilation,
that constitutes a fire hazard,
that is otherwise dangerous to human life or the public welfare,
that involves illegal or improper occupancy, or
that involves inadequate maintenance.

para.heading: Use.
para.text: "Use" means, unless the context indicates otherwise:
the purpose for which a building, structure, or land is used, occupied, or intended to be used or occupied, and
any activity, occupation, business, or operation carried out on land or in a building or structure.

para.heading: Zoning Code.
para.text: "Zoning Code" means the Baltimore City Zoning Code, including the accompanying Zoning District Maps.

para.heading: Residential Group R-3.
para.text: Residential occupancies in which the occupants are primarily permanent in nature, that are not classified as R-1, R-2, R-4, or I, and that comply with the Baltimore City Zoning Code, including:
buildings that do not contain more than two dwelling units,
care facilities that provide accommodations for 5 or fewer persons receiving care,
congregate living facilities (nontransient) with 5 or fewer occupants, including:
boarding houses (nontransient)
convents
dormitories
fraternities and sororities
monasteries,
congregate living facilities (transient) with 5 or fewer occupants including:
boarding houses (transient),
lodging houses (transient) with 5 or fewer guest rooms and 5 or fewer occupants.

para.heading: Permitted compliance with Residential Code.
para.text: The following facilities may be constructed in accordance with the International Residential Code, as long as an automatic fire sprinkler system is installed in accordance with § 313 {"Automatic Fire Sprinkler Systems"} of that Code:
a care facility for 5 or fewer persons receiving care within a dwelling unit, and
an owner-occupied lodging house with 5 or fewer guestrooms and 5 or fewer total occupants.

para.heading: Greenhouses.
para.text: Greenhouses:
unless otherwise classified as another occupancy, are classified as Use Group U; and
must comply with § 3112 {"Greenhouses"} of this Code.

para.heading: Fences.
para.text: Fences:
unless otherwise classified as another occupance, are classified as Use Group U; and
must comply with § 3118 {"Fences”} of this Code.

para.heading: Stairway door operation.
para.text: All stairway doors that are to be locked from the stairway side must be capable of being unlocked simultaneously, without unlatching, on a signal from the fire command station, on activation of the fire alarm system, or on loss of power to the building.

para.heading: Exterior walls.
para.text: Exterior walls shall be fire resistance rated in accordance with Table 601, based on the type of construction, and Table 705.5, based on the fire separation distance. The required fire-resistance rating of exterior walls with a fire separation distance of greater than10 feet (3048 mm) shall be rated for exposure to fire from the inside. The required fire-resistance rating of exterior walls with a fire separation distance of less than or equal to 10 feet (3048 mm) shall be rated for exposure to fire from both sides.

para.heading: Porch roofs – Abutting.
para.text: In new construction, renovation, or replacement of a porch roof that abuts another porch roof fire-retardant-treated wood sheathing shall be installed.

section.heading: Fire Pump and Riser Room Size

para.heading: Fire Pump Location.
para.text: Fire pump and associated equipment shall be located in a separate room that is enclosed with 2-hour fire-resistance-rated fire-separation assemblies. Installation shall comply with requirements of Article 695 of Part III ("Electrical Code”) of this Code.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Every new or renovated Assembly Group A, Business Group B, and Mercantile Group M occupancy, as those terms are defined in the International Building Code § 303, § 304, and § 309 with at least one public bathroom, and every City-owned or -occupied building with at least one public bathroom, must include a diaper-changing amenity in its public bathrooms, whether designated for men or women or both, or in another appropriate, sanitary space that both men and women can access.

para.heading: Exceptions.
para.text: This § 1209.4 does not apply to the following Assembly Group A, Business Group-B, and Mercantile Group M occupancies and City-owned or - occupied buildings:
Assembly Group A, Business Group B, and Mercantile Group M occupancies and City-owned or -occupied buildings undergoing renovations if the renovations do not require a building permit;
Assembly Group A, Business Group B, and Mercantile Group M occupancies and City-owned or -occupied buildings that prohibit entrance to minors; and

Assembly Group A, Business Group B, and Mercantile Group M occupancies for which the Building Official determines that the installation of a diaper-changing amenity is not feasible or would result in a failure to comply with applicable building standards governing the right of access for persons with disabilities are exempt from the requirements of this provision. City-owned or -occupied buildings are not included in this exemption.

para.heading: Compliance with other laws.
para.text: All diaper-changing amenities must comply with the requirements of this Baltimore City Building, Fire, and Related Codes Article and with any State and Federal laws, including the Americans with Disability Act, that deal with the installation of diaper-changing amenities.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Every new or renovated Assembly Group A, Business Group B, and Mercantile Group M occupancy, as those terms are defined in the International Building Code § 303, § 304, and § 309 with at least one public bathroom, and every City-owned or -occupied building with at least one public bathroom, must include a diaper-changing amenity in its public bathrooms, whether designated for men or women or both, or in another appropriate, sanitary space that both men and women can access.

para.heading: Exceptions.
para.text: This § 1210.4 does not apply to the following Assembly Group A, Business Group-B, and Mercantile Group M occupancies and City-owned or - occupied buildings:
Assembly Group A, Business Group B, and Mercantile Group M occupancies and City-owned or -occupied buildings undergoing renovations if the renovations do not require a building permit;
Assembly Group A, Business Group B, and Mercantile Group M occupancies and City-owned or -occupied buildings that prohibit entrance to minors; and

Assembly Group A, Business Group B, and Mercantile Group M occupancies for which the Building Official determines that the installation of a diaper-changing amenity is not feasible or would result in a failure to comply with applicable building standards governing the right of access for persons with disabilities are exempt from the requirements of this provision. City-owned or -occupied buildings are not included in this exemption.

para.heading: Compliance with other laws.
para.text: All diaper-changing amenities must comply with the requirements of this Baltimore City Building, Fire, and Related Codes Article and with any State and Federal laws, including the Americans with Disability Act, that deal with the installation of diaper-changing amenities.

para.heading: Splash Pads.
para.text: Bathroom facilities for splashs pad splash pads shall be provided in accordance with all applicable provisions of the ISPSC 2021. Bathrooms may not be provided for splash pads if one of the following conditions are met:
The splash pads are recirculating and have health and safety information posted as required by this Code or any other regulations and laws governing this Code.

A written agreement is in place between owners/operators of the splash pad and the adjoining local businesses or other organizations that allows splash pad patrons access to bathroom facilities located in the adjoining local businesses or other organizations.

para.heading: Reflectance.
para.text: Roof Coverings over conditioned spaces on low-slope roofs (roof slope < 2:12) on newly constructed buildings and additions to existing buildings shall have a minimum 3-year-aged solar reflective index of 78, as determined by the Cool Roof Rating Council.
Exceptions:
An addition to a roof that supports living vegetation and includes a synthetic, high quality waterproof membrane, drainage layer, soil layer, and lightweight medium plants.
Roof areas used as outdoor recreation space by the occupants of the building.
An area including and adjacent to rooftop photovoltaic and solar thermal equipment, totaling not more than 3 times the area that is covered with photovoltaic and solar thermal equipment.
Limited roof areas as determined by regulations promulgated by the Department of Housing & Community Development.
A roof, the area of which is less than 3% of the gross floor area of the building.

para.heading: Conflicts.
para.text: In the event of a conflict between § 1504.10 of this Code and City Code Article 6 {"Historical and Architectural Preservation"}, City Code Article 6 {"Historical and Architectural Preservation"} prevails.

para.heading: Rooftop decks.
para.text: Rooftop decks must comply with this § 1511.9 and with Chapter 16 {"Structural Design"} of this Code.

para.heading: Materials.
para.text: Rooftop decks must be constructed with approved materials in accordance with Chapters 19 through 26 of this Code.

para.heading: Notice to adjoining owners.
para.text: If a rooftop deck is to be supported by party walls:
the owners of the adjoining properties must be notified in writing, and
evidence of this notice must be submitted with the construction documents.

para.heading: Construction documents.
para.text: Construction documents for all rooftop decks must:
include dimensional setbacks, and
be signed and sealed by a professional architect or engineer licensed in Maryland.

para.heading: Clearances.
para.text: All rooftop decks must maintain all clearances otherwise required by this Code, including Chapter 8 {"Chimneys and Vents"} of the International Mechanical Code and § 230.24 {"Clearances"} of the National Electrical Code.

para.heading: Height.
para.text: No rooftop deck may be raised more than 2 feet (0.61 m) above the plane that is midway between the lowest and the highest points of the roof surface supporting the rooftop deck.

para.heading: Setbacks.
para.text: A rooftop deck must comply with:
the minimum setbacks specified in § 1511.9.6.1, and
any greater or additional setback requirements established by or under the Baltimore City Zoning Code and any applicable Urban Renewal Plan.

para.heading: Minimum setbacks.
para.text: A rooftop deck must comply with the following minimum setbacks:

tr.td: 8 feet (2.44 m) from face of building wall
Mansard Roof (steeply pitched front slope followed by flat roof) –

para.heading: Ordinary roofs, awnings, and canopies.
para.text: Ordinary flat, pitched, and curved roofs, and awnings and canopies other than opf fabric construction supported by a skeleton structure, must be designed for the following minimum live loads:

tr.td: Live Load (pounds/square foot of horizontal projection)
Rise 4" (102 mm) per foot to less than 12" (305 mm) per foot
Rise 12" (305 mm) per foot and greater
Arch or dome with rise less than 1/8 of span
Arch or dome with rise 1/8 of span to less than 3/8 of span
Arch or dome with rise 3/8 of span or greater

para.heading: Frost protection.
para.text: Except where otherwise protected from frost, foundation walls, piers, and other permanent supports of buildings and structures must be protected by one or more of the following methods:
extending 30" below grade,
constructing in accordance with ASCE 32, or
erecting on solid rock.

para.heading: Scope – General.
para.text: Mechanical appliances, equipment, and systems must be constructed. installed, and maintained in accordance with:
the International Mechanical Code (2021 Edition), as modified by Part V of this Code, and
the International Fuel Gas Code (2021 Edition), as modified by Part IV of this Code.

para.heading: Scope – Chimneys, fireplaces, barbecues.
para.text: Masonry chimneys, fireplaces, and barbecues must comply with:
Chapter 21 {"Masonry"} of this Code, and
the International Mechanical Code (2021 Edition), as modified by Part V of this Code.

para.heading: Scope.
para.text: The erection, installation, alteration, repairs, relocation, replacement, use, or maintenance of or addition to plumbing equipment and systems are governed by:
this Chapter,
the International Plumbing Code (2021 Edition) (the "IPC"), as modified by Part VI of this Code; and
for private sewage disposal systems, COMAR 26.04.02 {"Sewage Disposal and Certain Water Systems..."}.

para.heading: "Plumbing regulations".
para.text: Together, this Chapter 29 and the IPC are referred to in this Code as "plumbing regulations".

para.heading: Single-user toilet facility and bathing room fixture.
Family or assisted-use toilet and bath fixtures.
para.text: Fixtures located within accessible family or assisted-use toilet and bathing rooms required by the Maryland Accessibility Code (COMAR 09.12.53) are permitted to be included in the number of required fixtures for either the male or female occupants in assembly and mercantile occupancies.

para.heading: Signage.
para.text: Required public facilities must be provided with signs that designate the sex, as required by § 2902.2. Signs must be readily visible and located near the entrance to each toilet facility. Signs for accessible toilet facilities must comply with the Maryland Accessibility Code (COMAR 09.12.53).

para.heading: Gender-inclusive signage.
para.text: If separate facilities for each sex are not required, as permitted by the exceptions to § 2902.2 {"Separate facilities”} of this Code, then Article 15, § 43-3 {"Requirement for single-user restrooms”} of the City Code mandates that a public single-user restroom in a commercial or industrial establishment, a place of public accommodation, or a City-owned or -occupied building shall be:
made available for use by individuals of any gender, and
identified with gender-inclusive signage.

{Editor's Note: But see City Code Article 15, Subtitle 43 {"Public Restrooms"}, which requires the use of "gender-inclusive signage" to identify any "public single-use restroom" in a commercial or industrial establishment, a place of public accommodation, or a City-owned or -occupied building.}

section.heading: Parking Lots, Driveways, and Other Paved Surfaces

para.heading: Section inapplicable to special-event parking.
para.text: This § 3116 does not apply to special-event parking lots operating under and in compliance with City Code Article 15, Subtitle 13 {"Parking facilities – Special-Event Parking Lots"} as long as the lot complies with all other requirements applicable to the lot's principal occupancy, use, or structure.

para.heading: Driveway entrances.
para.text: All driveway entrances located on a public right-of-way must be constructed in accordance with the rules, regulations, and permit requirements of the Department of Transportation.

para.heading: Surface paving.
para.text: Parking lots, parking pads, driveways, and private roads must be paved with asphalt, brick, concrete, macadam, or stone block. Permeable paving systems may be utilized in accordance with the rules and regulations of the Department of Public Works. All paving must be able to support the design loads for the proposed vehicular traffic.

para.heading: Parking spaces.
para.text: The size, layout, and arrangement of parking spaces must comply with:
the Baltimore City Zoning Code,
the Maryland State Accessability Code, and
the rules and regulations of the City Planning Commission.

para.heading: Curbs or bumpers.
para.text: Curbs or bumpers must be installed for all parking spaces. Each curb or bumper must be:
made of concrete, wood, or an approved metal wheel stop,
at least 6 inches (152 mm) high and 8 inches (203 mm) wide,
securely fixed in place, and
located:
at least 4 feet (1.22 m) from the parking lot perimeter, or
for parking spaces that are parallel to the perimeter of the parking lot, at least 2 feet (0.61 m) from the perimeter.

para.heading: Surface drainage.
para.text: Storm drainage off paved surface areas, such as parking lots, playgrounds, and plazas, must be properly conveyed to paved alleys, paved streets, or other approved water courses.

para.heading: Limitations.
para.text: No drainage may be discharged:
so as to run or flow over any sidewalk or footway, except at a driveway with a depressed curb, or
across any adjoining property.

para.heading: Methods.
para.text: Drainage must be piped to a storm drain, to the street or alley, to a paved swale, or to another approved water course. The installation of piping, connections to storm drains, etc., must be made in accordance with the plumbing regulations of Chapter 29 {"Plumbing Systems"} of this Code.

para.heading: General.
para.text: This Chapter applies to every single-family dwelling, whether detached, semi-detached, or attached, and to all ground-floor dwelling units of any 2-family dwelling or of any multiple-family dwelling that contains 4 or fewer dwelling units, that:
is newly constructed on a vacant lot, and
receives funding or other assistance from the City or any City agency (including the Housing Authority of Baltimore City) by any one of the following methods:
a building contract or similar agreement that involves any Federal, State, or City funds,
acquisition, by gift, purchase, lease, or otherwise, of any real property for less than its appraised value, as determined by a certified appraiser,
preferential tax treatment, such as payments in lieu of taxes, tax increment financing, or similar benefit,
bond proceeds or issuance assistance, a loan, or similar financial benefit,
receipt under City authority of Federal or State construction funds, including Community Development Block Grant funds, and
except as otherwise specified in this section, receipt of any other form of funding or financial benefit from the City or a City agency.

para.heading: Exclusions.
para.text: This Chapter does not apply to:
additions to or remodelings of existing buildings, or
new construction for which City funding or assistance is limited to either or both:
a property tax credit under City Code Article 28, § 10-5 {"Newly constructed dwellings"}, and
waiver of a City lien on property where the lien exceeds the value of the property.

para.text: "Operator" has the meaning stated in § 202.2 of the Baltimore City Building Code.

para.heading: Owner.
para.text: "Owner" means any person that:
has a legal or equitable interest in the property,
is recorded in the land records as holding title to the property, or
otherwise has control of the property, with or without accompanying possession of the property, including:
a guardian of the person or estate of an owner,
a trustee, including a trustee in bankruptcy, of an owner, or
the personal representative of the estate of an owner.

para.heading: Person.
para.text: "Person" has the meaning stated in § 202.2 of the Baltimore City Building Code.

para.heading: Premises.
para.text: "Premises" means a lot or group of lots, together with all or any part of any structures on the lot or group of lots, considered as a unit devoted to a particular use, including accessory structures and open spaces required or used in connection with that particular use.

para.heading: Rooming house.
para.text: "Rooming house" means a building that:
is not a multiple-family dwelling, and

contains more than 2 rooming units occupied or designed or intended to be occupied by individuals who, even though they might share common areas and facilities, do not form a single housekeeping unit and do not provide compensation under a single lease for occupancy of the rooming house.

para.heading: Inclusions.
para.text: "Rooming house" includes a hotel, motel, bed and breakfast (as defined in Zoning Code § 1-303(f)), or boarding house.

para.heading: Rooming unit.
para.text: "Rooming unit" means any room or group of rooms that form a single habitable unit occupied or designed or intended to be occupied for sleeping or living, but not for cooking purposes.

para.heading: Strict liability offense.
para.text: "Strict liability offense" means an offense in which the prosecution in a legal proceeding is not required to prove knowledge or intent as a part of its case. It is enough to prove that the defendant either did an act that was prohibited or failed to do an act that the defendant was legally required to do.

para.heading: Structure.
para.text: "Structure" has the meaning stated in IPMC § 202 and, unless the context indicates otherwise, includes premises and lands.

para.heading: Trash.
para.text: "Trash" means rubbish, as defined in IPMC § 202.

para.heading: Workmanlike.
para.text: "Workmanlike" means executed in a skilled manner in accordance with the standards of the trade – e.g., generally plumb, level, square, in line, undamaged, and without marring adjacent work.

para.heading: Responsibility.
para.text: Except as provided in § 704 {"Fire Protection Systems"} of this Chapter, the owner and operator of the premises must provide and maintain fire safety facilities and equipment in compliance with these requirements.
